chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: MATE is a powerful but simple desktop environment with a strong focus on usability, accessibility, and internationalization. MATE is designed to be usable by everybody, regardless of technical expertise, disabilitites, or native language. MATE makes it easy for people to use their computers.

MATE provides a comprehensive developer platform that allow developers to create professional software that is easy to use and aesthetically pleasing. This document provides a high-level overview of the MATE platform along with links to detailed documentation on each part of the platform.

section.title: Who Should Read This Document
section.para: You should read this document if you want to create software using the MATE platform. Developing with the MATE platform will help you create consistent applications that integrate well into the user's desktop. This guide will introduce you to the various components of the platform, so you know which libraries can accomplish which tasks. This guide links to additional detailed documentation, so you can explore each component of the platform in more depth.
This guide will also be useful if you are picking a development platform for your software project. It will provide an overview how you can use the MATE platform to build useful software.

This guide also describes ways of extending the MATE desktop with plugins, panel applets, and other useful tools. If you want to develop additional functionality to plug into the MATE desktop, you should read this guide, particularly .
If you have existing software that you want to port to the MATE platform, you should see the online Guide For ISVs in addition to this guide.

section.title: The MATE Family
section.para: MATE is a global effort, with many contributors all over the world. MATE is a success because of its contributors and users. This section lists the web sites and conferences where you can learn more about MATE, as well as other organizations that work with MATE.

listitem.para: The primary web site for MATE users. It contains release information, downloads, and documentation.
The complete source for all MATE documentation. It contains all of the user and developer documentation produced by MATE, automatically built and updated for each release.
The web site for the MATE Foundation, the not-for-profit foundation that oversees the development of MATE.
The MATE bug trackers. Use this site to submit a bug report or feature request, or to track the status of a report.
The MATE wiki. Many projects within MATE now use the wiki as their primary web space. In additional, the wiki is often used to sketch out future development.

The old website for developer information. This once contained developer documentation and information about the usability, documentation, and translation teams. The content on this site has since been largely superseded by library.mate.org and live.mate.org. There may still be some information on this site that is not found elsewhere.
Information on MATE mailing lists. This site contains full archives of all MATE mailing lists.
The MATE Git repository, tracking all MATE source code back to the inception of the project.
The primary mailing list for MATE users.
Information and questions about development using the MATE platform.
The first place to go to get involved with MATE.
Information on accessibility in MATE applications.
Information on writing documentation for MATE applications.
Information about internationalization and localization of MATE applications.
Information on usability for MATE applications.

The primary conference for MATE users and developers. GUADEC is hosted annually in May or June. Each year, it is hosted in a different European city, making it an excellent excuse to see more of Europe. GUADEC features talks aimed at users, developers, and vendors.
The hacker get-together. The Summit is geared primarily at existing MATE developers, although there is often useful information for new developers. The Summit is hosted annually in Boston.
A casual get-together hosted annually at linux.conf.au.

The collaborative effort for interoperability and shared technology among desktop environments. Through freedesktop.org, MATE works with projects such as KDE and XFCE to make it easier for application developers to provide better experiences for their users.
The free web engine, and a whole lot more. MATE maintains close ties to the Mozilla development team to provide an overall better user interface.
The free office suite. MATE works with the OpenOffice.org development team to help provide a more unified interface when using the free office suite on MATE.

Freedom. Established in 1985, the Free Software Foundation has worked to create a complete free operating systems, giving its users the freedom to use, modify, and redistribute their software. As part of the GNU project, MATE aims to provide a fully free desktop environment.
